{{Infobox organization | image = StFrancisMis.png | caption = Lakota Chief Spotted Tail
requested Jesuit educators | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = | extinction = | type = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | coords = | language = | leader_title = Board of
Directors | leader_name = President
Fr. John Hatcher, S.J. | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title3 = | leader_title4 = Area | leader_name4 = {{convert|34|acre}} | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = [[Jesuit]], [[Catholic church|Catholic]] | budget = | remarks = | name = {{big|St. Francis Mission}} | former name = | image_border = | size = 260px | abbreviation = | merger = | established = {{Start date and age|1886 }} | location = Rosebud Indian Reservation
350 Oak St.
[[St. Francis, South Dakota]] | region_served = | membership = | general = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = [http://www.sfmission.org SF Mission] }} {{Infobox NRHP | name = St. Francis Mission | nrhp_type = hd | nocat = yes | image = St. Charles Borromeo church (St. Francis SD) from S 1.JPG | caption = St. Charles Borromeo Catholic Church | location= Rosebud Indian Reservation | locmapin = | built = | architecture = | added = June 20, 1975 | area = | governing_body = Local | refnum = 75001723{{NRISref|version=2010a}} }} [[File:Kateri.png|thumb|right|125px|Kateri Tekakwitha]] '''St. Francis Mission''' is a [[Roman Catholic]] mission complex on the [[Rosebud Indian Reservation]] in [[St. Francis, South Dakota]], among the [[Lakota people|Lakota]]-[[Sioux]] Native Americans. The mission was founded in 1886 by the [[Jesuits]] who were welcomed by [[Martin Marty (bishop)|Bishop Martin Marty]], and it soon grew to a large collection of buildings. Most of these were destroyed by a fire in 1916, but many were soon rebuilt. The mission complex includes 26 buildings, the most prominent of which are St. [[Charles Borromeo]] Church and the 1916 Drexall Hall, the latter a multifunction structure providing classrooms, meeting spaces, and residential spaces. The complex also includes one of two known copies of a statue of [[Kateri Tekakwitha]] by [[Joseph-Émile Brunet]].{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=75001723}}|title=NRHP nomination for St. Francis Mission|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2014-12-11}} The complex was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1975. ==History== The Jesuit presence in this area goes back to the 1840s when Fr. [[Pierre-Jean De Smet|Peter DeSmet]], S.J., was welcomed by the plains Indians and had contacts with the [[Lakota people|Lakota]]. Based on his reputation as a man who could be trusted, and on the Jesuit reputation as educators, in 1877 Chief Sinte Gleska (Spotted Tail), leader of the Sicangu Lakota, and Chief Red Cloud, leader of the [[Oglala Lakota|Oglala]], obtained permission from President [[Rutherford B. Hayes]] "to get Catholic priests. Those who wear black dresses. These men will teach us how to read and write English." This led to the arrival of a Jesuit Father and brother soon after 1881 and, with financial help from St. [[Katherine Drexel]], the completion of a large building in 1886.{{Cite news|url=http://americamagazine.org/issue/5147/100/life-lakota|title=Life with the Lakota: A Jesuit mission on the rez|date=2012-07-30|newspaper=America Magazine|access-date=2017-02-20|language=en}} In 1888 [[Franciscan]] Sisters Kostka, Rosalia, and Alcantara came to teach in the school which they named after [[Francis of Assisi|St. Francis]]. Jesuit Fr. Florentine Digmann who had come with the sisters went on to establish 37 mission stations on the Rosebud Reservation. Since 1974 the school, locally called Sapa Un Ti ("where the Black Robes live"), has been run by the tribe, independently from the Jesuit mission. The many chapels have been replaced by six parishes on the reservation.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/about/mission-history|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} Mission History|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}} ==Current programs== In 2016 three Jesuit priests along with [[Jesuit Volunteer Corps]] members{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/about/jesuit-volunteers|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} Jesuit Volunteers|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}} were serving the Mission, with assistance from Lakota – a [[deacon]], several commissioned [[Lay ministry|lay ministers]], and numerous volunteers – working among the 20,000 who remain on the reservation. The Mission supports high school equivalency ([[GED]]) and adult education, Icimani Ya Waste Recovery Center, the White River Recovery Center, the CYO Religious Education Center in Rosebud, and the Wiwila Wakpala after-school center in Spring Creek, along with the following works at the Center:{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/about|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} About|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}} *'''Sapa Un Catholic Academy''', based on the [[NativityMiguel Network of Schools|Jesuit Nativity model]] of schools, began in 2013 teaching both English and Lakota to 10-12 students a year in grades K through 5. The express purpose of the school is to enable more Lakota to graduate from colleges and universities and become leaders among their people. Open to students of all religions, its tuition is low and it offers scholarships. Cultural enhancement opportunities include a month-long summer camp.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/programs/sapa-un-academy|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} Sapa Un Academy|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}} *'''Lakota Studies''' is an effort to preserve the Lakota language and cultural heritage, with a view especially to its spiritual richness. In pursuit of this purpose Deacon Ben Black Bear, Jr., is translating the [[New Testament]] into Lakota, along with prayers and [[catechism]] instructions. In 2008 the program produced a new, more complete Lakota dictionary.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/programs/lakota-studies|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} Lakota Studies|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.southdakotamagazine.com/todd-county|title=Land of the Burnt Thigh|access-date=2017-02-20}} *'''Family Recovery''' program, funded by the [[Hazelden Betty Ford Foundation|Betty Ford Institute]], addresses the family dynamics behind addiction problems, in a 12-hour program that would facilitate recovery in the context of the whole family situation. The program is conducted by a trained staff in a different community on the reservation each month. Many have gone on to participate in other Mission programs such as [[Al-Anon]] and [[Alcoholics Anonymous]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/programs/recovery-2|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} Recovery|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}} *'''Suicide prevention''': In a single year beginning in October 2007, over 1% of the 20,000 on the reservation attempted suicide and 27 succeeded, compared to a national rate of 11.26 suicides.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/statistics/suicide/index.shtml|title=NIMH » Suicide|website=www.nimh.nih.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-02-20}} In hearings before the [[United States Senate Committee on Indian Affairs]], more leadership activities were called for to address the problem,{{Cite web|url=http://www.usmedicine.com/2010-issues/may-2010/more-mental-health-resources-needed-to-battle-teen-suicides-in-american-indian-and-alaska-native-communities|title=More Mental Health Resources Needed to Battle Teen Suicides in American Indian and Alaska Native Communities : U.S. Medicine|website=www.usmedicine.com|access-date=2017-02-20}} warranting an emphasis on the mission's Academy program. In line with testimony before the same committee, the Mission provides a crisis hotline [[24/7]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/programs/suicide-prevention|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} Suicide Prevention|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}}[http://www.catholicnews.com/services/englishnews/2016/a-ministry-of-mercy-tackles-suicide-epidemic-on-lakota-reservation.cfmb ''Catholic News Service'', April 7, 2016.] *'''KINI 96.1 FM radio''' is a work of the Mission and covers south central [[South Dakota]] and north central [[Nebraska]]. offering a complete spectrum of news on the reservation and national scenes, along with weather, music, local sports, and religious education.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/programs/kini-radio|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} KINI Radio|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}} It reaches over 20,000 listeners.{{Cite web|url=http://thepracticingcatholic.com/2011/02/08/the-st-francis-mission-among-the-lakota/|title=The St. Francis Mission Among the Lakota|last=says|first=St Francis Mission Online Donation Campaign {{!}} The Practicing Catholic|date=2011-02-08|website=The Practicing Catholic|access-date=2017-02-20}} *'''A dental clinic''' with volunteer dentists has been running since 2012.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/programs/dental-clinic|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} Dental Clinic|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}} *'''Buechel Memorial Lakota Museum''' is named for the noted linguist and ethnologist Fr. [[Eugene Buechel]], S.J., who came to the Mission in 1902 and died there in 1954. It houses a collection of over 2000 items related to [[ethnography]] and over 42,000 photos.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmission.org/programs/museum|title=St. Francis Mission {{!}} Museum|website=www.sfmission.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-20}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.travelsouthdakota.com/about-south-dakota/sd-tribes-plains-indians/sioux-tribes/rosebud-sioux-tribe|title=Rosebud Sioux Tribe|date=2014-12-01|newspaper=TravelSouthDakota.com|access-date=2017-02-20|language=en}} The Mission is also represented in a Special Collection in the Marquette University archives.{{Cite web|url=http://www.marquette.edu/library/archives/Mss/SFM/SFM-history.shtml|title=St. Francis Mission Records Catholic Jesuits Sisters of St Saint Francis of Penance and Christian Charity Lakota Sioux Sicangu Brule Indians Rosebud Reservation South Dakota {{!}} Marquette Archives {{!}} Raynor Memorial Libraries {{!}} Marquette University|website=www.marquette.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-02-20}} ==See also== *{{cite book| authorlink = | title =The Blackrobe in the land of the wigwam : St. Francis Mission, St. Francis, South Dakota.| publisher =Jost & Kiefer| date =1920| location =Quincy, IL | url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/blackrobe-in-the-land-of-the-wigwam-st-francis-mission-st-francis-south-dakota/oclc/9558935|accessdate=May 27, 2016}} *[http://www.sfmission.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Consultation-Report-for-Lower-Brule-Cheyenne-River-and-Standing-Rock-Reservations-Phase-IV.pdf Inculturation project. Accessed 26 April 2016] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Todd County, South Dakota]] {{National Register of Historic Places}} {{Roman Catholic Diocese of Rapid City}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Coord|43|8|18.74|N|100|54|16|W|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saint Francis Mission}} [[Category:Jesuit development centres]] [[Category:Historic districts on the National Register of Historic Places in South Dakota]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Todd County, South Dakota]] [[Category:Properties of religious function on the National Register of Historic Places in South Dakota]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1886]] [[Category:Romanesque Revival church buildings in South Dakota]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches completed in 1916]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Todd County, South Dakota]] [[Category:Churches in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rapid City]] [[Category:Poverty-related organizations]] [[Category:Community-building organizations]] [[Category:Development charities based in the United States]] [[Category:Social welfare charities based in the United States]] [[Category:Cultural promotion organizations]]
